title: New Brexit High Court case launched to force Boris Johnson to avoid no-deal
text:

Boris Johnson faces yet another legal fight over Brexit after a union applied for an injunction to avoid no-deal on October 31.

The Independent Workers' Union of Great Britain (IWGB) has filed a claim at the High Court, in a bid to stop the Tory PM undermining a law that says he should delay Brexit .

The 'Benn Act' will order Mr Johnson to request a three-month extension on October 19 if there's no Brexit deal by that point.

But despite claiming he will obey the law, the Prime Minister has insisted Britain will leave the EU on October 31 anyway - and he'd rather be "dead in a ditch" than delay.

Now the IWGB will seek to hold him to his legal duties in the name of protecting workers' rights.

Their injunction, if granted, will "restrain the Prime Minister from undermining the purpose of the Benn Act" - for example, by telling EU leaders to reject the delay he's asking for.

(Image: James Veysey/REX)

(Image: Getty Images)

The union is bringing the case with two migrant workers, Maritza Castillo Calle and Wilson Ayala, and a UK-born “gig economy” courier working for TDL, Alex Marshall.

IWGB has brought a number of cases in recent years which have relied on EU legislation, including a £1 million holiday pay claim against NHS contractor The Doctors Laboratory.

IWGB general secretary Dr Jason Moyer-Lee said: "Low-paid workers need every tool possible to fight exploitative bosses and EU law has been crucial in that regard.

"In a no-deal Brexit, Tory Brexiteers will have free rein to water down employment rights and workers will lose access to the European Court and the Charter of Fundamental Rights, which the IWGB has relies on to defend its members.

"We will do everything possible to protect our members' rights and that's why we are bringing this case."

(Image: Hollie Adams)

Wilson Ayala, one of the claimants, said: "I came to this country looking for a decent life, but quickly discovered that, in the UK, precarious migrant workers have to fight for every single one of our rights, whether through protests and strikes, or through legal action.

"Now Brexit has put not only our immigration status in play, but also the basic legal framework that we can use to fight for better employment rights.

"In the same way that we have fought for and won dignity at work, we will fight for our basic employment rights."

The case may be joined with a High Court action brought by civil liberties organisation Liberty in a bid to force the Prime Minister to comply with the Benn Act.

It comes after campaigners lost a bid to get two court orders which would have directly forced Boris Johnson to delay Brexit.

The group led by SNP MP Joanna Cherry is appealing today in Edinburgh's Court of Session after a judge said the orders were "neither necessary nor appropriate".

The first order would have prevented the PM "taking any action that would undermine or frustrate" the Act - such as delaying his 'delay letter', "encouraging" EU leaders to reject an extension, or issuing a parallel letter to the EU asking them not to grant an extension.

The second order would have directly forced Mr Johnson to sign and send the delay letter before 3pm on October 19.

But the UK government won over the Scottish court by finally promising, in writing, that it would obey the Benn Act after all.
description: The Independent Workers' Union of Great Britain is seeking a High Court injunction to force the Prime Minister to delay Brexit
